Yes, it is true that saturated fats are needed for hormone production in the body. Saturated fats play a crucial role in maintaining proper hormone levels and manufacturing steroid hormones, which are essential for building and repairing tissue, as well as regulating numerous physiological functions.

However, it is important to note that the body only requires a small amount of saturated fat to sustain these processes. Consuming too much saturated fat may increase the risk of developing health problems, such as heart disease, by raising cholesterol levels and contributing to inflammation.

Therefore, it is generally recommended to limit the intake of saturated fats and seek to include healthy unsaturated fats in the diet instead. This can be done by focusing on including plant-based oils like olive oil or avocados into the diet, as well as omega-3 rich foods like salmon or walnuts.
